vignette:
Frank Young, a 40-year-old business executive, was brought for a psychiatric consultation by his wife. While Mr. Young sat quietly beside her, she reported that a change had come over him during the last 6 months. He was either quiet and withdrawn or uncharacteristically irritable. He had begun to drink alcohol to excess in social situations, sometimes embarrassing her. He often came home late, or not at all, claiming to have been at the office. When away from home, he rarely answered phone calls and text messages. She wondered if he was having an affair. Mr. Young denied seeing anyone else and indicated he had just been having a hard time.

After his wife left the psychiatrist’s office, Mr. Young reported a great deal of stress at work over the last year as he tried to deal with industry-wide setbacks and personal financial losses. He said he felt down and depressed most of the time. He reported difficulty sleeping most nights, loss of interest in his wife and children, low energy, and feelings of failure and self-criticism. He had frequent thoughts of wanting to be dead and of suicide, but he denied any suicidal intent or plans.

When asked about the alcohol, he acknowledged that he had been drinking heavily for at least 6 months. When asked about other substances, he asked about therapeutic confidentiality and then acknowledged that he had been using cocaine several times per week for about 9 months. He kept his cocaine use from his wife because he knew she would be judgmental. In the beginning, cocaine put him in a reliably positive, optimistic mood, and he found that he could more successfully churn through large volumes of otherwise tedious and discouraging work. Although his work required some socializing in the evening, he also began to regularly go to bars in the evening just so that he would have a place to comfortably combine cocaine with alcohol. He craved the high from cocaine, went out of his way to obtain it, and spent a lot of time getting high that he would previously have been spending with his family.

When asked to clarify the sequence of work stress, cocaine use, and depression symptoms, he reported that he had felt worried and discouraged about work for a year, but the feelings of depression, loss of interest, irritability, insomnia, and low self-esteem had not begun until about 6 months earlier, 3 months after he had begun to use cocaine regularly. He experienced those depressive symptoms most of the day every day, whether or not he had taken cocaine within the last several days.

Mr. Young denied any previous episodes of depression, other mood or anxiety disorders, or suicide attempts. He drank socially. He had experimented with cannabis and cocaine as a teenager but had never developed a pattern of regular use or impairment until the past year.
diagnosis:
1. Cocaine use disorder, moderate
2. Substance (cocaine)-induced depressive disorder
model_thoughts:
**My Diagnostic Reasoning Process**

Okay, here's how I'd approach this case, step-by-step, drawing on my expertise in psychiatric diagnosis, especially concerning substance-related disorders and mood disorders. My primary goal is to provide a clinically sound and accurate DSM-5-TR diagnostic list with ICD-10 codes.

First, I meticulously *extracted and organized* the clinical data. I focused on the presenting problem (change in behavior, depressive symptoms), the history of present illness (detailed information from both the wife and the patient), substance use history (including detailed criteria for cocaine use disorder), and past psychiatric history (specifically the denial of prior mood disorders). The timeline, in this case, is crucial, so I carefully noted the sequence of events: work stress, initiation of cocaine use, onset of depressive symptoms, and the relationship between cocaine and alcohol use.

The second part involved *diagnostic reasoning and differential diagnosis*. My primary concern was to distinguish between a primary mood disorder (like Major Depressive Disorder) and a substance/medication-induced disorder. The *timeline* was the key factor. I recognized that the depressive symptoms emerged *after* the initiation of heavy cocaine use (and heavy alcohol use), pointing me toward Substance-Induced Depressive Disorder. I assessed the patient's symptoms against the DSM-5-TR criteria for Major Depressive Episode, but noted the clear temporal relationship with substance use. The patient's heavy cocaine use (several times per week) and concurrent heavy alcohol use strongly suggest a substance-induced origin. I considered the effects of both cocaine intoxication and withdrawal. The fact that the patient reported being depressed most of the time, whether or not he had used cocaine recently, made me consider withdrawal effects.

The vignette's explicit phrasing (depression onset 3 months *after* cocaine initiation) was a critical clue that I interpreted as evidence *against* a primary Major Depressive Disorder in this case. Also the patient had only *started* drinking heavily at the same time the depression started. I considered, but immediately ruled out, Adjustment Disorder, even though there was a 1-year history of work stress, because the patient's symptoms met the criteria for a Major Depressive Episode, and met criteria for substance use disorders. I also noted the potential for alcohol-induced depression, given the heavy use.

I assessed whether the patient met the criteria for Stimulant Use Disorder (Cocaine) and Alcohol Use Disorder, noting that he exhibited social impairment, time spent obtaining and using the substance, craving, and using substances despite knowledge of problems. These were all confirmed by the information provided.

Given the timeline, I determined the most appropriate primary diagnosis to be **Cocaine-Induced Depressive Disorder**. The depression, as described, emerged *after* the established regular cocaine use. I also acknowledged that the heavy alcohol use started at the same time and could contribute to the depression, thereby adding **Alcohol-Induced Depressive Disorder** as a likely diagnosis. However, because cocaine use was the more significant factor in the context of the vignette, I placed cocaine first. I *did* consider Major Depressive Disorder as an alternative. Clinically, I would have explored the possibility, especially if the patient's symptoms were believed to precede the substance use, but I would *still* list the substance-induced disorder based on the data. However, based on the *vignette* alone, this was a substance-induced case. The prompt also favored listing active diagnoses, rather than a differential of possibilities.

I then considered what constituted "secondary diagnoses." In this context, given my expert understanding of coding conventions, comorbidities, and the prompt's instructions, I included **Stimulant Use Disorder (Cocaine)** and **Alcohol Use Disorder**. These conditions were co-occurring and were key factors in the patient's presentation. Finally, since the patient had reported work-related stress for a year *before* the cocaine use and depressive symptoms, I chose to include **Adjustment Disorder with Anxiety** to capture that antecedent (pre-morbid) state. I carefully reviewed the DSM-5-TR's exclusion criteria for Adjustment Disorder, but the text's description of "worry" predating the drugs indicated a preceding Adjustment Disorder with anxiety. This was an expert-level interpretation because the diagnostic rubric emphasized understanding the timeline.

This resulted in the following structured list of DSM-5-TR diagnoses with corresponding ICD-10 codes:

1.  **Cocaine-induced depressive disorder** (F14.24)
2.  **Stimulant use disorder** (F14.20)
3.  **Alcohol use disorder** (F10.20)
4.  **Alcohol-induced depressive disorder** (F10.24)
5.  **Adjustment disorder with anxiety** (F43.22)

Based on the clinical vignette and DSM-5-TR criteria, here are the top 5 most likely diagnoses:

1. **Cocaine-induced depressive disorder** - F14.24
2. **Stimulant use disorder** - F14.20
3. **Alcohol use disorder** - F10.20
4. **Alcohol-induced depressive disorder** - F10.24
5. **Adjustment disorder with anxiety** - F43.22

vignette:
George Anderson, a 73-year-old married man, was referred to a psychiatrist for an evaluation of depression after screening positive on the Geriatric Depression Scale during a neurology appointment. For most of the 2 years since his diagnosis with Parkinson’s disease, Mr. Anderson had coped well and continued to engage in many of his usual activities. His wife of 49 years noted that 1–2 years before developing Parkinson’s disease, Mr. Anderson had become somewhat less enthusiastic and motivated compared with his baseline personality, but not to the point of causing any concern or impairment. The only other neuropsychiatric symptom preceding his Parkinson’s diagnosis was his wife’s report that during the past 5 years he frequently “thrashed about” while asleep.

Three months prior to the referral, however, Mr. Anderson began to decline social invitations from family and friends. He reported that he had withdrawn socially because he had lost pleasure in things that used to excite him, although he denied persistent feelings of sadness or worry. He recognized that he was not his “usual self” and tried, to no avail, to give himself “pep talks.” He had worked as a high school science teacher until retirement at age 67, and reported having learned “the power of seeing the glass half full” from his students. He felt frustrated that he could not “snap out of it” for the first time in his life but was hopeful about getting professional help. He denied wishing for death, explaining that although he was not afraid of death, he wanted to enjoy life as long as possible. He added, “God does not give me more than I can handle. I can’t ask for a better family, and I have had a full life.”

Other new symptoms over the prior few months included increasing fatigue, impaired concentration and memory, unintentional weight loss, and sleep-onset insomnia. Further history on his more chronic sleep symptoms revealed that, around 3:00 a.m. or 4:00 a.m. on most nights, Mr. Anderson began violently moving his extremities and moaning as though in distress, all while still seemingly asleep in bed. He often awakened his wife with these movements and occasionally struck her in his sleep. She sometimes used a different bedroom because of this. When he awoke from such an incident, he was coherent and briefly anxious, often reporting that he had been dreaming of swimming or running from something.

His wife took over driving shortly after his Parkinson’s disease diagnosis, but Mr. Anderson was otherwise independent in activities of daily living such as paying bills and managing his medications. His wife described him as “maybe a little more forgetful” over the past few years, but neither of them was concerned about this mild memory loss.

Past medical history included prostate cancer (in remission), glaucoma, and gout. Labs from his recent neurology visit were unremarkable, including blood counts, serum chemistries, thyroid function, and vitamin B12 levels. Family psychiatric history was positive only for a granddaughter with ADHD. He denied past problematic substance use and all current substance use except two or three glasses of wine monthly. He denied any previous depressive episodes, psychiatric treatment, or psychiatric evaluations.

On mental status examination, Mr. Anderson was pleasant, cooperative, and interpersonally engaging. Resting tremor, shuffling gait, hypophonia, and bradykinesia all were evident at mild to moderate levels. He occasionally smiled, but his affect was difficult to fully gauge because of masked facies. He reported his mood as “blah.” There was no evidence of psychosis.

On cognitive testing, he had some difficulty on the Trail Making Test part B, figure copying, and word-list recall, the latter being helped by category prompts. On a standardized brief cognitive assessment, he scored 25 out of 30 points, which was in the normal range.
diagnosis:
1. Depressive disorder due to another medical condition (Parkinson’s disease), with major depressive–like episode
2. Rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder
model_thoughts:
**Diagnostic Reasoning Summary**

Okay, here's how I'm thinking through this case. First, I'm wearing my psychiatrist hat, using the DSM-5-TR as my guide, and keeping in mind that I'm aiming for Level 5 ACGME performance in Data Extraction and Diagnostic Reasoning. My task is to produce a list of diagnoses and codes. No clinical reasoning is needed in the final output.

I've got George Anderson, 73, and the main flag is a positive screen on the Geriatric Depression Scale, which came up during a neurology appointment. My first step is really diving into the details. I'm building a clinical picture using data extraction and organization. The acute decline (past three months), with anhedonia and social withdrawal, is immediately grabbing my attention. There's an absence of sadness, he is "blah". There's also frustration, fatigue, concentration and memory issues, weight loss, and sleep-onset insomnia. He denies any active suicidal ideation, which is very important. Then, I'm noting the Parkinson's Disease (PD) diagnosis two years ago, and this history of RBD for five years. The motor and cognitive deficits are there, and I need to establish a diagnosis of sleep disorder.

Next, I'm assessing the patient's cognitive and functional status. I'm seeing independent living activities, but difficulty with driving, and complaints of being "forgetful." The MoCA/MMSE score of 25/30 isn't terrible, but it is borderline normal, with trouble on executive function tests. Medically, prostate cancer in remission, and some glaucoma and gout, which I need to rule out. Labs are unremarkable. Alcohol use is negligible. MSE shows the PD signs: tremor, shuffling, hypophonia, bradykinesia, masked facies, and "blah" mood, no psychosis.

Then, the critical task: Differential Diagnosis. I am going to try and build my diagnoses, starting with the mood episode. Is it a Major Depressive Episode? Anhedonia, weight loss, insomnia, fatigue, concentration issues, and a three-month timeline. The question is: MDD or Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition (PD)? I am leaning towards the latter because of the known comorbidity and causal link, especially given the acute onset *after* the PD diagnosis, although there was a prodromal apathy phase, as the DSM-5-TR suggests, as well as the acute nature of the current 3-month depressive episode.

Cluster 2 is the sleep disturbance. I am seeing violent movements and vocalization in REM-rich periods, with alertness upon waking. Since the patient has Parkinson's, and the symptoms are prodromal, I'm diagnosing Rapid Eye Movement Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD). The prompt's emphasis on F-codes is making me hunt for the appropriate code. I know G-codes are used frequently, but I need to map it to an F-code.

In cluster 3, I am assessing cognition. PD and those subjective and objective memory and executive deficits are key. The score is borderline. He's functionally independent. So, it's *Mild* Neurocognitive Disorder Due to Parkinson's Disease. My reasoning is the decline exceeding age norms, but independent living. This clearly is not Major NCD. The apathy is common in NCD.

Cluster 4: I need to consider personality. The "less enthusiastic" period prior to PD may be a personality change due to a medical condition (apathy), but it could be "Unspecified Anxiety Disorder" or adjustment issues. The insomnia might be anxiety-related, but it's part of the depression.

So, I'm now ordering the diagnoses. Primary is the depression, due to its referral and severity. That means *Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition* (Parkinson's). I'll use F06.32.

Second is *Rapid Eye Movement Sleep Behavior Disorder* – F51.8.

Third, *Mild Neurocognitive Disorder Due to Parkinson's Disease* – F06.7 (using the F-code to reflect the mild cognitive decline).

Fourth, *Personality Change Due to Another Medical Condition* - Apathy F07.0.

Fifth, Insomnia, *Insomnia Disorder* - F51.01.

Now, I'm running these through another filter. Does that align with the vignette? Referral – depression, PD, the "thrashing" sleep, the cognitive status, and the "less enthusiastic" bit all accounted for. The sleep, cognitive, mood, and apathy pieces are coming together. I'm double-checking the code mapping, particularly RBD.

Here, I encounter a coding issue. RBD usually uses G47.52, but I have to use F-codes. Technically, I'm forced
model_diagnosis:
1. Depressive disorder due to another medical condition - F06.32
2. Mild neurocognitive disorder due to known physiological condition - F06.7
3. Other specified sleep-wake disorder - F51.8
4. Personality change due to known physiological condition - F07.0
5. Insomnia disorder - F51.01

vignette:
Helena Bates was a 27-year-old single administrative assistant who presented for a psychiatric evaluation and treatment for depression. She had recently begun an intensive outpatient program after a first lifetime hospitalization for an impulsive overdose following the breakup of a 2-year relationship. She said she had been feeling increasingly sad and hopeless for 1–2 months prior to the breakup. About a month before her admission, she began seeing a new psychotherapist who told her she had “borderline traits” and “situational mood swings.”

During these 4–8 weeks, Ms. Bates’s mood had been moderately depressed throughout the day most days, with no diurnal variation and intact mood reactivity. She had recently gained about 10 pounds from “overeating comfort food and junk.” She denied prominent irritability or argumentativeness. She described her self-esteem as “none” and had found it hard to feel motivation or to concentrate on routine tasks. By contrast, sometimes she would have “bursts” of nonstop thinking about her estranged boyfriend and devising ways to “get him back,” alternating with “grieving his loss.” She described times of being flooded with strategies to regain his interest (including purchasing a full-page newspaper “open letter” to him) and recently found herself awake until 5:00 or 6:00 a.m. journaling or calling friends in the middle of the night “for support.” She would then “trudge through the day” without fatigue after only 2–3 hours of sleep. These symptoms began prior to her hospitalization. She denied drug or alcohol misuse and self-injurious behavior. Until this particular breakup, she denied a history of particularly intense or chaotic relationships, as well as a history of suicidal thoughts or gestures. Indeed, Ms. Bates seemed horrified by her own impulsive overdose.

Previously, Ms. Bates had seen a counselor in high school for “moodiness” and poor grades. She became “depressed” in college. At that time, she began escitalopram and psychotherapy, but improved quickly and stopped both after a few weeks. While in the hospital following her suicide attempt, she started taking vilazodone and quetiapine at bedtime “for sleep.”

Ms. Bates was the youngest of three children who grew up in a middle-class suburban home. She attended public school and a state college as “mostly a B student” and hoped to someday go to law school. She described herself as having been a “quiet, anxious” child and “not a troublemaker.” Her older brother abused multiple substances, although Ms. Bates said she herself had never used illicit substances. Her older sister was treated for “panic attacks and depression,” and Ms. Bates knew of several aunts and cousins whom she thought were “depressed.”

On examination, Ms. Bates was a pleasant, well-related, casually but appropriately dressed, moderately overweight woman, appearing her stated age, who made good eye contact. Her speech was somewhat rapid and verbose but interruptible and nonpressured. She had no abnormal motor movements, but she gestured dramatically and with excessive animation. Her mood was depressed, and her affect was tense and dysphoric but with full range and normal responsivity. Ms. Bates’s thought processes were somewhat circumstantial but generally coherent, linear, and logical. Her thought content was notable for passive thoughts that she might be better off dead, but without intent or plan; she had no delusions, hallucinations, or homicidal thoughts. Her higher integrative functioning was grossly intact, as were her insight and judgment.
diagnosis: Major depressive disorder with mixed features
model_thoughts:
**My Diagnostic Process: A Deep Dive**

Okay, here’s how I’m approaching this. First, I need to understand the task. I'm acting as an expert psychiatrist, and the prompt requires me to identify the top five most likely diagnoses with ICD-10 codes, all based on a clinical vignette. I'm aiming for a Level 5 performance, which means pulling out subtle details, connecting patterns, thinking outside the box, and prioritizing based on the nuances of the presentation. My final output is a list, no reasoning required, but the rigor of the thought process is paramount.

Now, into the clinical data. The patient, Helena Bates, is a 27-year-old single administrative assistant with a chief complaint of depression. The history is critical. She had her first hospitalization due to an impulsive overdose following a breakup. Before the breakup, she experienced 1-2 months of increasing sadness, which is key. During the past 4-8 weeks, we see moderate depression, mood reactivity (potentially atypical), weight gain, low self-esteem, and poor motivation. And then, there’s a crucial shift: "Bursts" of non-stop thinking and "schemes". The critical symptom: decreased need for sleep, functioning without fatigue on only 2-3 hours of sleep! Even more impulsivity with risky behavior and rapid speech with “flooded” strategies.

Her past psychiatric history reveals "moodiness" in high school and a past depression in college for which she started, but quickly stopped, escitalopram, because she "improved quickly." That rapid response to an SSRI is a huge flag for bipolarity. Recent therapy suggested "borderline traits," but the patient's history doesn't fully support this, particularly concerning her lack of chaotic relationships and no self-harm before this event.

The family history is also telling: substance abuse in the brother, panic/depression in the sister, and a family history of mood disorders. No substance misuse reported here.

The mental status exam shows rapid, verbose speech, dramatic gesturing, a depressed mood with full affect but tense dysphoria, and circumstantial thought processes. She's currently on vilazodone and quetiapine.

Now the diagnostic reasoning. We have two key symptom clusters: depressive symptoms (sadness, hopelessness, weight gain, low self-esteem) and manic/hypomanic symptoms (decreased sleep, racing thoughts, goal-directed activity, risky behavior, rapid speech). These symptoms have appeared recently, within the 4-8 week window. The decreased need for sleep screams a manic or hypomanic episode.

Evaluating Bipolar I versus II is critical. Bipolar I requires a manic episode, defined by elevated/irritable mood, increased energy/activity for one week (or hospitalization). The hospitalization is the clue. The newspaper ad, the calls at 4 AM, the 2-3 hours of sleep—these behaviors constitute a distinct period of abnormality with marked impairment. The hospitalization is *for* the overdose which is a key trigger. Under the DSM-5-TR, hospitalization means a manic episode *by definition*. The simultaneous depression and manic symptoms (rapid speech) suggest a mixed episode. The recent history supports Mania/Hypomania, particularly given the rapid response to the SSRI in the past.

Considering the severity, hospitalization, and the history of rapid response to an SSRI, my top diagnosis is **Bipolar I Disorder**, potentially a *current* episode, mixed or depressed, because the symptoms are current. The primary issue is a mood disorder, and I'll include the "mixed" presentation with the appropriate F-code. However, if there are questions about the severity of those symptoms, I'll include Bipolar II, and other differentials as well.

I’m also reevaluating the Borderline diagnosis, and while this could also be a differential, the absence of prior self-harm, stable history, and the episodic nature of the impulsivity strongly supports the mood disorder as the primary explanation.

Other differentials include Major Depressive Disorder (ruled out by the manic/hypomanic symptoms), Cyclothymic Disorder (too severe), Other Specified Bipolar Disorder (if full duration criteria aren't met), Adjustment Disorder (though I think the biological symptoms are stronger) and Substance/Medication-Induced Mood Disorder (symptoms predate medication).

My top five are now solidified. I’ve refined this to:

1.  **Bipolar I Disorder, current episode mixed, severe, without psychotic features - F31.63** This covers the current presentation, severity, and recent history. Given the mixed state and exam findings, I believe this code most accurately reflects this patient.

2.  **Bipolar II Disorder - F31.81** As a strong secondary differential if the "high" is judged as hypomanic.

3.  **Other specified bipolar and related disorder
model_diagnosis:
1. Bipolar I disorder, current episode mixed, severe, without psychotic features - F31.63
2. Bipolar II disorder - F31.81
3. Other specified bipolar and related disorder - F31.89
4. Major depressive disorder, recurrent, severe, with mixed features - F33.2
5. Borderline personality disorder - F60.3

vignette:
Ian Campbell was a 32-year-old architect who presented for psychiatric consultation because he was floundering at work. His boss had expressed concern after he failed to make progress on a simple project. When Mr. Campbell explained that he had been distracted by problems at home, his boss suggested that more seemed wrong. Mr. Campbell called his internist, who sent him to a neurologist, who referred him for psychiatric evaluation.

Mr. Campbell had encountered this problem, difficulty concentrating, before. In college, after his father died of a chronic illness, Mr. Campbell had been unable to study and had taken time off. Twice at his prior job, he experienced episodes lasting months in which he had difficulty making decisions. One of these intervals followed a romantic setback.

The patient’s mother and sister had been diagnosed with major depressive disorder and treated successfully with medication. A maternal uncle had committed suicide.

The current impairment’s onset accompanied the breakdown of Mr. Campbell’s marriage of 6 years. Two months earlier, his wife had filed for divorce, announcing that she would live in the distant city her work had taken her to. Mr. Campbell had expected to feel relief; he said his wife had been hostile throughout the marriage. He had begun to entertain fond thoughts of a coworker. Nevertheless, he felt “flat”—unable to imagine a future.

Closer questioning revealed that Mr. Campbell’s problems went beyond impaired cognition. He described apathy and diminished energy. Jazz was a passion, but he no longer attended recitals—although impaired concentration probably played a role as well. Listening, the psychiatrist noted probable retardation of speech. Mr. Campbell said that his employer had mentioned that he was “moving in slow motion.” The problems were worse in the mornings. In the evenings, Mr. Campbell noticed a spark of energy. He put on music and reviewed reports that he had ignored during the workday.

Mr. Campbell declined to characterize himself as sad. He was pleased that the marriage was ending. But the psychiatrist was struck by her own affect in Mr. Campbell’s presence; she felt glum, pessimistic, even weepy.

She questioned Mr. Campbell at length about depressed mood, changed sleep and appetite, feelings of guilt or worthlessness, and thoughts of death. None of these attributions, he said, applied. Nor had he had indicators of disorders that can be confused with depression. Between episodes of impairment, he felt and functioned well.

The psychiatrist decided that the problem at hand was close enough to depression to warrant treatment. Factors that influenced her decision included the partial syndromal presentation, diurnal variation, periodic recurrence, lack of future orientation, and her own empathic experience. She proposed psychotherapy centered on Mr. Campbell’s decompensation in the face of loss. He insisted that he did not see the impending divorce in that light. The two agreed on brief psychotherapy supplemented by antidepressants. Within weeks, Mr. Campbell was functioning at full capacity. During the treatment, the psychiatrist was unable to elicit evidence of depressive symptoms beyond those noted in the initial history. All the same, she was convinced that the impaired concentration was a sign and symptom of something very much like major depressive disorder.
diagnosis: Other specified depressive disorder (depressive episode with insufficient symptoms)
model_thoughts:
**Diagnostic Reasoning - Expert Psychiatrist Perspective**

Okay, here’s how I’m approaching this, step-by-step. First, I need to understand exactly what’s being asked of me. I'm a psychiatrist, being asked to provide a diagnosis for Ian Campbell based on this vignette. The key constraint is the ACGME rubric – Level 5 requires precise data extraction and reasoning, but I can’t actually *output* my reasoning. I must adhere to the DSM-5-TR, and provide a numbered list of the *top 5 diagnoses* with ICD-10 F-codes—no extraneous text, just the codes and diagnoses. So, I must have excellent reasoning (internal) and perfect output format.

Next, I need to get my mental scratchpad ready for data extraction. Ian Campbell, 32, architect. His main complaint is that he's "floundering at work," struggling to concentrate, and feels slow. The onset of this aligns directly with his wife filing for divorce, which suggests a clear trigger. While he denies feeling sadness, the reported "flat" affect and anhedonia are red flags. The symptoms include cognitive difficulties (concentration and decision-making), mood (flatness, apathy, hopelessness), neurovegetative (diminished energy, psychomotor retardation which is obvious), and anhedonia (jazz recitals). Sleep and appetite are thankfully unaffected, and there's no guilt, worthlessness, or suicidal ideation—that's good.

Regarding the psychiatric history, he had a similar struggle in college after his father’s death and two prior episodes involving indecision and poor functioning, with full recovery in between. Family history reveals a strong genetic loading—his mother and sister have MDD and responded well to medication; an uncle committed suicide. Observations from the mental status exam confirm psychomotor retardation (speech and movement), and an objective observation of glum, pessimistic, weepy that the patient denies.

A crucial point is his response to treatment: full recovery with short-term therapy and antidepressants.

Now the real diagnostic work begins. I've got to consider the *key clinical features*–recurrent episodes of significant impairment. Given the evidence, I must give priority to Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). The presence of anhedonia, psychomotor retardation (even if subtle, it is present and observable), fatigue, and cognitive dysfunction, plus that familial loading, strongly supports this.

I must account for the “sadness” denial. The DSM-5-TR makes it clear that depression can be present without the patient *saying* they are sad, so I can use the clinician's observation of the patient's affect. The patient denying sadness is actually part of severe depression, especially with the Melancholic features. The clinical observations meet the necessary criteria.

Now, I look at the other possibilities to rule them out. Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia) isn’t likely because the episodes are distinct, not chronic, and there are good intervals in between. Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood is *possible*, given the divorce, but the severity and recurrence argue for a deeper, biological mood disorder, also the patient does not acknowledge the loss as the trigger. If I can't find 5 symptoms for MDD, Adjustment Disorder is a strong contender. "Other Specified Depressive Disorder" is a *strong* choice if this is a "partial syndromal presentation." If symptoms aren't met, this becomes a frontrunner. Bipolar II Disorder must be considered because of the psychomotor slowing and flat affect (less clear without hypomania). I can't see the patient has that, though it *is* an essential rule-out. The "spark of energy" is most likely diurnal variation. Unspecified Depressive Disorder is a broad category, so it can't be first on my list. GAD? No. I am not seeing anxiety, mostly the neurovegetative and psychomotor stuff.

I then went back and selected my most likely diagnosis to create my final list of differential diagnoses. The diagnostic list needed to be solid, because the rubric focuses on differential diagnoses and not merely a diagnosis. I thought of this as a list of possibilities in the patient's record, or an "Assessment" rather than "Diagnosis."

After the deliberation, my final list must reflect that the patient is suffering from a Major Depressive Disorder, probably with Melancholic features:

1.  Major depressive disorder, recurrent, severe without psychotic features - F33.2
2.  Other specified depressive disorder - F32.89
3.  Adjustment disorder with depressed mood - F43.21
4.  Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) - F34.1
5.  Unspecified depressive disorder - F32.9
model_diagnosis:
1. Major depressive disorder, recurrent, severe without psychotic features - F33.2
2. Other specified depressive disorder - F32.89
3. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood - F43.21
4. Major depressive disorder, recurrent, moderate - F33.1
5. Unspecified depressive disorder - F32.9

vignette:
Logan was a 12-year-old boy who was referred to mental health care for long-standing anxiety about losing his parents and relatively recent fears about getting a severe disease.

Although his parents described a long history of anxiety, Logan’s acute problem began 5 weeks prior to the consultation, when he watched a television show about rare and fatal diseases. Afterward, he became scared that he might have a hidden disease. His parents reported three “panic attacks” in the prior month, marked by anxiety, dizziness, sweats, and shortness of breath. About that same time, Logan began to complain of frequent headaches and stomachaches. Logan’s own theory was that his bodily aches were caused by his fears about being ill and about his parents going away, but the pain was still uncomfortable. He insisted he was not scared about having more panic attacks but was petrified about being left sick and alone. These illness fears developed several times a week, usually when Logan was in bed, when he “felt something” in his body, or when he heard about diseases.

Logan had begun to suffer from anxieties as a young child. Kindergarten was notable for intense separation difficulties. He was briefly bullied in third grade, which led to his first panic attacks and worsening anxiety. According to his parents, “there always seemed to be a new anxiety.” These included fear of the toilet, the dark, sleeping alone, being alone, and being pestered.

Logan’s most persistent fear revolved around his parents’ safety. He was generally fine when both were at work or at home, but when they were in transit, or anywhere else, he was generally afraid that they would die in an accident. When the parents were late from work or when they tried to go out together or on an errand without him, Logan became frantic, calling and texting incessantly. Logan was predominantly concerned about his mother’s safety, and she had gradually reduced her solo activities to a minimum. As she said, it felt like “he would like to follow me into the toilet.” Logan was less demanding toward his father, who believed his wife had been too soft and overprotective.

Logan and his family underwent several months of psychotherapy when Logan was age 10. The father said therapy helped his wife become less overprotective, and Logan’s anxiety seemed to improve. Logan’s mother agreed with this assessment, although she said she was not sure what she was supposed to do when her son was panicking whenever she tried to leave the house or whenever he worried about getting a disease.

Logan’s developmental history was otherwise unremarkable. His grades were generally good. His teachers agreed that he was quiet but had several friends and collaborated well with other children. He was quick, however, to negatively interpret the intentions of other children. For example, he tended to be very sensitive to any indication that he was being picked on.

Logan’s family history was pertinent for panic disorder, agoraphobia, and social anxiety disorder in the mother. The maternal grandmother was described as “at least as” anxious as Logan’s mother. The father denied psychiatric illness in his family.

On examination, Logan was a friendly, articulate boy who was cooperative and goal directed. He was generally in a “good mood” but cried when talking about his fears of dying and getting sick. He denied suicidality and hopelessness but indicated he was desperate to get over his problems before starting high school. His cognition was good. His insight and judgment appeared intact except as related to his anxiety issues.
diagnosis: Separation anxiety disorder with panic attacks
model_thoughts:
**Analysis and Formulation for Logan's Case**

Alright, let's break down this clinical vignette for Logan. The task is to identify the most probable DSM-5-TR diagnoses, and this is where I'd start. First, I have to pinpoint the primary issue. Logan is a 12-year-old boy whose core struggle is clear: anxiety stemming from separation. His history clearly supports this from kindergarten and onwards. This separation anxiety is the chronic underpinning. His acute presentation of illness-related fears, in my view, is a manifestation of this already present anxiety.

The central diagnosis, without a doubt, is **Separation Anxiety Disorder (F93.0)**. The criteria fit perfectly, especially the long-standing nature, the distress when separated, and the behaviors used to manage it, and this is the most enduring and impairing aspect of his presentation.

Second, I have to consider the anxiety's pervasiveness. Logan exhibits chronic and shifting worries. There is "always a new anxiety" to deal with, and his somatic complaints align with this. His acute presentation focuses on illness-related fear (5 weeks), which would be better described as a "worry about an illness." Given the "shifting" aspect of his concerns and the duration (> 6 months), this would be **Generalized Anxiety Disorder (F41.1)**, which encapsulates his overall anxious disposition, and in children, these worries can manifest as somatic pain.

Third, the somatic component demands attention. He has frequent headaches and stomachaches. The connection to his fears is significant, even though he lacks insight in the pain. Given the presence of genuine somatic symptoms, the best diagnosis is **Somatic Symptom Disorder (F45.1)**. This highlights the high level of anxiety about the symptoms even if he understands they are a result of his anxieties. This takes precedence over Illness Anxiety Disorder since he experiences somatic symptoms.

Fourth, I have to consider his panic attacks. Despite his denial of being afraid of the attacks themselves, their presence in the context of feeling bodily sensations (i.e. headache) or hearing about diseases is relevant, and a family history is positive. Given that he has these recurrent attacks (even if the fear is of the illness, and not the attacks), I must diagnose **Panic Disorder (F41.0)**. It is a key differential.

Finally, I have to consider any other possible diagnosis. Logan's sensitivity to being picked on and a bullying history is significant, but it does not fully warrant diagnosis of Social Anxiety Disorder. I would consider the diagnosis of **Social Anxiety Disorder (F40.10)**, but the fact that he has friends and can collaborate at school makes the diagnosis less clear. I will diagnose this based on a family history, but should note it in the discussion as a comorbidity. The anxiety related to illness could be considered a **Specific Phobia (F40.298)**, however, due to the acute nature of the illness fear, this is better described by the somatic disorder or panic attacks.

Therefore, my most likely diagnoses are:

1.  Separation Anxiety Disorder (F93.0)
2.  Generalized Anxiety Disorder (F41.1)
3.  Somatic Symptom Disorder (F45.1)
4.  Panic Disorder (F41.0)
5.  Social Anxiety Disorder (F40.10)
model_diagnosis:
1. Separation Anxiety Disorder - F93.0
2. Generalized Anxiety Disorder - F41.1
3. Somatic Symptom Disorder - F45.1
4. Panic Disorder - F41.0
5. Social Anxiety Disorder - F40.10

vignette:
Maria Greco was a 23-year-old single woman who was referred for psychiatric evaluation by her cardiologist. In the prior 2 months, she had presented to the emergency room four times for acute complaints of palpitations, shortness of breath, sweats, trembling, and the fear that she was about to die. Each of these events had a rapid onset. The symptoms peaked within minutes, leaving her scared, exhausted, and fully convinced that she had just experienced a heart attack. Medical evaluations done right after these episodes yielded normal physical exam findings, vital signs, lab results, toxicology screens, and electrocardiograms.

The patient reported a total of five such attacks in the prior 3 months, with the panic occurring at work, at home, and while driving a car. She had developed a persistent fear of having other attacks, which led her to take many days off work and to avoid exercise, driving, and coffee. Her sleep quality declined, as did her mood. She avoided social relationships. She did not accept the reassurance offered to her by friends and physicians, believing that the medical workups were negative because they were performed after the resolution of the symptoms. She continued to suspect that something was wrong with her heart and that without an accurate diagnosis, she was going to die. When she had a panic attack while asleep in the middle of the night, she finally agreed to see a psychiatrist.

Ms. Greco denied a history of previous psychiatric disorders except for a history of anxiety during childhood that had been diagnosed as a “school phobia.”

The patient’s mother had committed suicide by overdose 4 years earlier in the context of recurrent major depressive disorder. At the time of the evaluation, the patient was living with her father and two younger siblings. The patient had graduated from high school, was working as a telephone operator, and was not dating anyone. Her family and social histories were otherwise noncontributory.

On examination, the patient was an anxious-appearing, cooperative, coherent young woman. She denied depression but did appear worried and was preoccupied with ideas of having heart disease. She denied psychotic symptoms, confusion, and all suicidality. Her cognition was intact, insight was limited, and judgment was fair.
diagnosis: Panic disorder
model_thoughts:
**Diagnostic Formulation: Maria Greco - Case Review & Differential**

Alright, let's break down this clinical presentation. Maria Greco, a 23-year-old female, walks in with a clear-cut case demanding a comprehensive diagnostic formulation. We're dealing with recurrent episodes of palpitations, shortness of breath, sweating, trembling, and the dreaded fear of dying – the red flags are immediate.

My first thought is **Panic Disorder** (F41.0). The recurrent, unexpected nature of these panic attacks is the cornerstone. The fact they hit during work, home, driving, even *nocturnally* screams Panic Disorder. Plus, she's showing anticipatory anxiety and avoids work, exercise, and driving, which solidifies this. This is the primary diagnosis.

Next, the avoidance behavior is critical. Maria's dodging work and driving because she's terrified of having these panic attacks. That is **Agoraphobia** (F40.00). The DSM-5-TR is clear; this is a separate diagnosis if these avoidances exist, even if Panic Disorder is present. Escape is a constant thought.

Now, her conviction that she has heart disease despite a clean medical workup is the next piece. Even though these somatic symptoms are explained by the panic attacks, her fixation on them is a critical factor. This points strongly towards **Somatic Symptom Disorder** (F45.1). The ongoing maladaptive thoughts and anxiety about her somatic symptoms separate it from a brief acute panic. The panic attacks are the somatic "symptoms" driving health anxiety and a lack of acceptance of medical clearance.

Her anxious appearance and history of "school phobia" (which could be social anxiety or separation anxiety) lead me to consider **Generalized Anxiety Disorder** (F41.1). The baseline anxiety and worry are crucial. The history of childhood anxiety further justifies this diagnosis.

Finally, the family history of suicide and the reported mood decline, sleep disturbance, and social withdrawal are concerning. Even though Maria *denies* depression, a clinical evaluation warrants us to consider and, potentially, rule out, **Major Depressive Disorder** (F32.9). Given the history and presentation, it has to be a differential, given the other diagnoses present.

In summary, my diagnoses are:

1.  Panic disorder - F41.0
2.  Agoraphobia - F40.00
3.  Somatic symptom disorder - F45.1
4.  Generalized anxiety disorder - F41.1
5.  Major depressive disorder - F32.9
model_diagnosis:
1. Panic disorder - F41.0
2. Agoraphobia - F40.00
3. Somatic symptom disorder - F45.1
4. Generalized anxiety disorder - F41.1
5. Major depressive disorder - F32.9

vignette:
Nadine was a 15-year-old girl whose mother brought her for a psychiatric evaluation to help with her long-standing shyness.

Although Nadine was initially reluctant to say much about herself, she said she felt constantly tense. She added that the anxiety had been “really bad” for several years and was often accompanied by episodes of dizziness and crying. She was generally unable to speak in any situation outside of her home or school classes. She refused to leave her house alone for fear of being forced to interact with someone. She was especially anxious around other teenagers, but she had also become “too nervous” to speak to adult neighbors she had known for years. She said it felt impossible to walk into a restaurant and order from “a stranger at the counter” for fear of being humiliated. She also felt constantly on her guard, needing to avoid the possibility of getting attacked, a strategy that really only worked when she was alone in her home.

Nadine tried to conceal her crippling anxiety from her parents, typically telling them that she “just didn’t feel like” going out. Feeling trapped and incompetent, Nadine said she contemplated suicide “all the time.” In the month before her mother finally brought her in for a psychiatric evaluation, Nadine had begun to cut herself on her thighs to “feel pain and relieve stress.” No one in the family was aware of this development.

Nadine had always been “shy” and had been teased at recess since she started kindergarten. The teasing had escalated to outright bullying by the time she was in seventh grade. The bullying took on a cultural/racially motivated undertone; Nadine and her family were of a different ethnicity than the vast majority of her schoolmates. For 2 years, day after difficult day, Nadine’s peers turned on her “like a snarling wolf pack,” calling her “stupid,” “ugly,” and “crazy.” Not infrequently, one of them would stare at her and tell her she would be better off committing suicide. One girl (the ringleader, as well as a former elementary school chum) hit Nadine on one occasion, giving her a black eye. Nadine did not fight back. This event was witnessed by an adult neighbor, who told Nadine’s mother. When Nadine’s mother asked her about the incident, Nadine denied it, saying she had “fallen” on the street. She did, however, mention to her mother “in passing” that she wanted to switch schools, but her delivery was so offhand that at the time, her mother casually advised against the switch. Nadine suffered on, sobbing herself to sleep most nights and wishing that she would not wake up.

Full of hope and ideas of escape from the bullies and their narrowness, Nadine transferred to a specialty arts high school for ninth grade. Although the bullying ceased, her anxiety symptoms paradoxically worsened. She felt even more unable to venture into public spaces and felt increasingly embarrassed by her inability to develop the sort of independence typical of a 15-year-old. She said she had begun to spend whole weekends “trapped” in her home and had become scared to even read by herself in the local park. Nadine’s social anxiety had evolved into true agoraphobia. She had nightly nightmares about the bullies in her old school. Her preoccupation with suicide grew.

Her parents had thought she would outgrow being shy and sought psychiatric help for her only after a teacher remarked that her anxiety and social isolation were keeping her from making the sort of grades and doing the sort of extracurricular activities that were necessary to get into a good college.

Nadine described her mother as loud, excitable, aggressive, and “a little frightening.” Her father was a successful tax attorney who worked long hours. Nadine described him as shy in social situations (“He’s more like me”). Nadine said she and her father sometimes joked that the goal of any evening was to avoid tipping the mother into a rage. Nadine added that she “never wanted to be anything like her mother.”
diagnosis:
1. Social anxiety disorder, severe
2. Posttraumatic stress disorder, moderate
3. Agoraphobia, severe
model_thoughts:
**Diagnostic Reasoning for Nadine, Age 15**

Alright, let's break this down. First, the task: diagnose Nadine using the DSM-5-TR, aiming for the highest level of performance. I see a 15-year-old girl, presenting with "long-standing shyness" and reported "constant tension." My mind instantly starts sifting through the data, looking for symptom clusters.

I'm zeroing in on a few key areas immediately. We have:

*   **Social Anxiety/Fear of Scrutiny:** This is a clear red flag given the history of bullying. I see the inability to speak outside of home or in class, the fear of interaction, and the anxiety around both peers and known adults. This has been going on for years.
*   **Agoraphobia:** This seems significant. We're talking about refusal to leave the house alone, inability to go into public, feeling trapped, and fear of simple things like reading in a park. It seems this stems from the social anxiety.
*   **Trauma/PTSD:** The bullying is severe, racially motivated, with verbal abuse, physical assault, and even death threats. The "snarling wolf pack" imagery really stands out. The nightmares, constant vigilance, and avoidance behaviors point towards PTSD.
*   **Depressive/Suicidal features:** Sobbing, suicidal ideation, self-harm (cutting), and feelings of hopelessness - this is critical. I need to understand if this is a secondary response to the anxiety or if depression is a primary issue.
*   **Selective Mutism:** The statement "Generally unable to speak in any situation outside of her home or school classes" is key. It's not just avoidance, but a specific inability to speak in certain settings.

I'm thinking: Social Anxiety is definitely present. I need to distinguish it from the Agoraphobia which the vignette states evolved from the social anxiety. PTSD is very clear given the direct impact of the bullying. The bullying creates the trauma. MDD appears to be a factor with suicidal ideation. Selective Mutism is distinct.

Next, I'm digging deeper into the symptoms, using the DSM-5-TR, thinking about the duration, severity, and functional impairment. Then, I'll go through differential diagnosis to make sure that other disorders can be ruled out. Generalized Anxiety Disorder doesn't quite fit, given how specific the fears are. Avoidant Personality Disorder is possible but less likely given her age and the acute presentation of anxiety and trauma. Panic Disorder is possible; however, the dizziness seems more related to the social/trauma triggers.

I'll start with the most obvious: Social Anxiety Disorder (F40.10). It's the central complaint and describes her “long-standing shyness” and “fear of interaction.”

Next, PTSD (F43.10) is also primary. The bullying qualifies as severe trauma, and the intrusion, avoidance, hypervigilance, and negative mood alterations all fit.

Third, Agoraphobia (F40.00). The refusal to leave the house, the anxiety about being in public places, and the explicit mention in the vignette support this.

The fourth diagnosis is Major Depressive Disorder (F32.2) (single episode, severe). The suicidal ideation, cutting, and hopelessness are all very concerning. Is it "recurrent" or "single"? Based on the data, the symptoms appear to be continuous and severe.

Fifth, Selective Mutism (F94.0). This diagnosis is supported because she "generally unable to speak in any situation outside of her home or school classes."

Let's summarize this:

1.  Social Anxiety Disorder - F40.10
2.  Posttraumatic Stress Disorder - F43.10
3.  Agoraphobia - F40.00
4.  Major Depressive Disorder, single episode, severe without psychotic features - F32.2
5.  Selective Mutism - F94.0
model_diagnosis:
1. Social anxiety disorder - F40.10
2. Posttraumatic stress disorder - F43.10
3. Agoraphobia - F40.00
4. Major depressive disorder, single episode, severe without psychotic features - F32.2
5. Selective mutism - F94.0

vignette:
Olaf Hendricks, a 51-year-old married businessman, presented to an outpatient psychiatrist with problems relating to periodically feeling helpless and lacking confidence. He reported that he usually feels fine except when he is confronted with his inability to travel by airplane. His only daughter had delivered a baby in the prior year, and although he desperately wanted to meet his first granddaughter, he felt unable to fly across the Atlantic Ocean to where his daughter lived.

The patient’s anxiety about flying had begun 3 years earlier when he was on an airplane that landed during an ice storm. He had last flown a year earlier but had cried during both takeoff and landing; he had then found himself unable to return from that trip by airplane and instead took a train from Rome to Amsterdam. He had gone with his wife to an airport one additional time, 1 year prior to the evaluation, to fly to his daughter’s wedding in the United States. Despite having drunk a significant amount of alcohol, Mr. Hendricks felt unable to board the airplane. After that failed effort, he tended to feel intense anxiety when he even considered the possibility of flying. Anxiety about business trips had led him to decline a promotion as well as an external job offer. Mr. Hendricks sees himself as a “family man” and feels terrible that he failed to attend his daughter’s wedding and has not yet been able to meet his granddaughter.

Aside from guilt and regret related to his inability to fly, Mr. Hendricks denied other symptoms of depression and anxiety. He had increased his alcohol consumption to three glasses of wine nightly in order to “unwind,” but denied any history of alcohol complications or withdrawal symptoms. He also denied a family history of psychiatric problems.

He denied experiencing anxiety in other situations, indicating that his colleagues saw him as a forceful and successful businessman who could “easily” deliver speeches in front of hundreds of people. When specifically asked, he reported that as a child, he had been “petrified” that he might get attacked by a wild animal. This fear had led him to refuse to go on family camping trips or even on long hikes in the country. As an adult, he said that he had no worries about being attacked by wild animals because he lived in a large city and took vacations by train to other large urban areas.
diagnosis:
1. Specific phobia, situational (flying on airplanes)
2. Specific phobia, animals
model_thoughts:
**Diagnostic Reasoning Summary**

Okay, here's my thought process. The prompt sets the stage: Expert Psychiatrist, tasked with diagnosing Olaf Hendricks using DSM-5-TR, level 5 ACGME standard – so I'm aiming for nuanced, accurate diagnoses based on subtle cues. No reasoning in the output, just the list. I've got the vignette.

First, I extract the core data: Olaf, 51, married, fear of flying (aerophobia) kicking in three years ago after a rough landing. The severity is there – crying, inability to fly for important events, avoidance impacting his work and family, and anticipatory anxiety. The triggers are specific. Substance use is noted; an increase in alcohol use to cope. There's a history of a childhood fear (wild animals), now mostly resolved by environmental engineering/avoidance, not necessarily exposure.

Now, my diagnostic reasoning starts. Specific Phobia (Situational) is screaming at me as the primary: It ticks all the boxes – marked fear, immediate anxiety, avoidance, out-of-proportion fear, lasting longer than six months, significant impairment, and it's not better explained by anything else. Situational specifier, boom.

Then, the differential. I've got to consider PTSD, given the traumatic origin, but it doesn't quite fit the criteria; no intrusion symptoms, etc. Adjustment Disorder is a quick "no" because the symptoms are chronic, and Specific Phobia supersedes. Panic Disorder – attacks are expected, not unexpected, so that's out. Agoraphobia? It has components of the fear of public transport, but that fear is isolated. Alcohol Use Disorder is a strong maybe; he's self-medicating and increasing his intake. Social Anxiety is easily ruled out; he's a confident public speaker. Generalized Anxiety Disorder is possible, but the anxiety is focused on the phobia.

Synthesizing, the top contenders are Specific Phobia, which is the definite diagnosis. Alcohol Use Disorder, potentially mild but significant due to the coping mechanism, and should be considered as an active problem. Then, I think of the trauma that sparked it. Should that be listed? I'm debating whether he has met PTSD criteria. The adjustment disorder is valid given that the patient has lost important life events (granddaughter, wedding) due to the phobia. It feels like an addition, so that is included too.

I must make the 5 diagnoses.

The animal phobia is a historical context, and must be considered.

And finally, my best pick:
1. Specific Phobia (Situational)
2. Alcohol Use Disorder (Mild)
3. Adjustment Disorder (Depressed Mood)
4. Agoraphobia
5. Panic disorder

I've checked the ICD-10 codes, F40.248, F10.10, F43.21, F40.00, F41.0. This accounts for the main diagnosis, substance issue, the emotional impact and the other components of the distress. And Panic Disorder is the one that's closer than PTSD.
I am now certain. Let's provide the final output.
model_diagnosis:
1. Specific phobia, situational type - F40.248
2. Alcohol use disorder, mild - F10.10
3. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood - F43.21
4. Agoraphobia - F40.00
5. Panic disorder - F41.0

vignette:
Peggy Isaac was a 41-year-old administrative assistant who was referred for an outpatient evaluation by her primary care physician with a chief complaint of “I’m always on edge.” She lived alone and had never married or had children. She had never before seen a psychiatrist.

Ms. Isaac had lived with her longtime boyfriend until 8 months earlier, at which time he had abruptly ended the relationship to date a younger woman. Soon thereafter, Ms. Isaac began to agonize about routine tasks and the possibility of making mistakes at work. She felt uncharacteristically tense and fatigued. She had difficulty focusing. She also started to worry excessively about money and, to economize, she moved into a cheaper apartment in a less desirable neighborhood. She repeatedly sought reassurance from her office mates and her mother. No one seemed able to help, and she worried about being “too much of a burden.”

During the 3 months prior to the evaluation, Ms. Isaac began to avoid going out at night, fearing that something bad would happen and she would be unable to summon help. More recently, she avoided going out in the daytime as well. She also felt “exposed and vulnerable” walking to the grocery store three blocks away, so she avoided shopping. After describing that she had figured out how to get her food delivered, she added, “It’s ridiculous. I honestly feel something terrible is going to happen in one of the aisles and no one will help me, so I won’t even go in.” When in her apartment, she could often relax and enjoy a good book or movie.

Ms. Isaac said she had “always been a little nervous.” Through much of kindergarten, she had cried inconsolably when her mother tried to drop her off. She reported seeing a counselor at age 10, during her parents’ divorce, because “my mother thought I was too clingy.” She added that she had never liked being alone, having had boyfriends constantly (occasionally overlapping) since age 16. She explained, “I hated being single, and I was always pretty, so I was never single for very long.” Nevertheless, until the recent breakup, she said she had always thought of herself as “fine.” She had been successful at work, jogged daily, maintained a solid network of friends, and had “no real complaints.”

On initial interview, Ms. Isaac said she had been sad for a few weeks after her boyfriend left, but denied ever having felt worthless, guilty, hopeless, anhedonic, or suicidal. She said her weight was unchanged and her sleep was fine. The patient denied psychomotor changes. She did describe significant anxiety, with a Generalized Anxiety Disorder–7 score of 18, indicating severe anxiety.
diagnosis: Generalized anxiety disorder
model_thoughts:
**My Diagnostic Thought Process**

Alright, let's break this down. As an expert, I need to methodically approach this clinical vignette. The primary task is clear: diagnose, using DSM-5-TR, with ICD-10 codes, following ACGME Level 5 standards for both data extraction and diagnostic reasoning. No clinical *reasoning* in the final product; just the list. I'm focused solely on psychiatric diagnoses.

First, I extracted the key data. Peggy Isaac, 41-year-old female, presents with being "always on edge." The precipitating factor is a breakup eight months ago. This is key. Post-breakup, we see a cascade of symptoms: agonizing over routine tasks, fear of mistakes, tension, fatigue, difficulty focusing. She's excessively worried about money. There's significant behavioral change: moving to a worse neighborhood, seeking reassurance, and a progression to avoidance - first at night, then during the day. The core fear? "Something bad would happen and she would be unable to summon help." She's avoiding grocery stores, and now is reliant on food delivery. Critically, she's relaxed *inside* her apartment.

Her developmental and social history illuminates the present. "Always a little nervous," separation anxiety in kindergarten, and being "too clingy" during her parents' divorce at age 10. She's never liked being alone, with serial monogamy since 16, constantly seeking relationships and hating being single. She was previously successful at work, social, and exercise.

Then, there is the mental status and symptom review. Her GAD-7 score is 18 (severe). Mood-wise, she was sad for a few weeks after the breakup but *denies* any major depressive symptoms (worthlessness, guilt, hopelessness, anhedonia, suicidality, weight or sleep changes).

Based on this, my diagnostic reasoning starts.

*   **Agoraphobia:** This is the most acute and functionally impairing presentation, the most prominent current symptom. The fear of being unable to escape or get help is explicit. The avoidance (not going out, food delivery) is clear. It meets the six-month duration criterion.
*   **Generalized Anxiety Disorder:** "Always on edge," fatigue, concentration difficulties, excessive worry about multiple things (work, money, being a burden). The GAD-7 score confirms the severity. The duration also fits. While Agoraphobia can overlap with Panic, she doesn't report true panic attacks, so I'll be sure to distinguish those.
*   **Separation/Dependency Issues:** A history of separation anxiety, "never liked being alone," serial relationships, and the decompensation after the breakup *screams* dependence and attachment issues. I considered Separation Anxiety Disorder, Dependent Personality Disorder, and Borderline Personality Disorder. Borderline seems less likely based on the vignette, so either Separation Anxiety or Dependent Personality are the best fits.
*   **Depressive Symptoms:** Denies SIGECAPS, so Major Depressive Disorder is unlikely. Adjustment Disorder is also unlikely because of the duration and the fit for other anxiety disorders.

Now the prioritization is key.

1.  **Agoraphobia:** The *most* debilitating, the "housebound" behavior and the fear of "no help."
2.  **GAD:** Chronic anxiety, tension, and worry.
3.  **Dependent Personality Disorder:** Lifetime pattern.
4.  **Separation Anxiety Disorder:** Relevant due to childhood and the precipitant event.
5.  I need a 5th, but the vignette *specifically* mentions the fear of "something terrible happening," which could indicate Panic Disorder.

*Re-evaluation of the key questions.* Does she meet criteria for Separation Anxiety Disorder *currently*? Is it primary or does Dependent Personality capture the *need* better, in which case it is more dependent, and the current presentation is now Agoraphobia/GAD? No, the focus is now the agoraphobia and GAD, but the precipitant was the loss of the attachment figure. However, a review of the text indicates she does not focus on separation from attachment figure. Dependent PD seems more consistent with the text provided. The history is there, but I need to focus on what is currently presenting. Separation anxiety has become a risk factor.

So, the final list:

1.  Agoraphobia (F40.00)
2.  Generalized anxiety disorder (F41.1)
3.  Dependent personality disorder (F60.7)
4.  Separation anxiety disorder (F93.0)
5.  Panic disorder (F41.0)
model_diagnosis:
1. Agoraphobia - F40.00
2. Generalized anxiety disorder - F41.1
3. Dependent personality disorder - F60.7
4. Separation anxiety disorder - F93.0
5. Panic disorder - F41.0

vignette:
A psychiatric transplant liaison service was called to evaluate Robert Jennings, a 50-year-old married white man, for a liver transplant in the context of an alcohol use disorder, advanced cirrhosis, and no other prior psychiatric history. Several weeks earlier, he had been hospitalized with acute alcohol-associated hepatitis and diagnosed with end-stage liver disease. Prednisolone 40 mg/day was prescribed for treatment of the hepatitis. Prior to that hospitalization, he had been unaware that his alcohol consumption was seriously damaging his health and was shocked to learn that he would eventually require a liver transplant. Upon discharge, he began an addiction treatment program that was mandatory for him to be listed for possible transplantation.

Outpatient psychiatric consultation was requested by the transplant team after the patient’s family expressed concern that he had recently become increasingly irritable and anxious and seemed to be having difficulty coping with the requirements for transplantation. Mr. Jennings’s primary care physician had recently prescribed alprazolam 0.5 mg as needed for his anxiety. This was initially helpful, but after several days his family noticed he seemed more irritable, lethargic, and forgetful.

When interviewed, the patient said that he had been tired for months prior to the diagnosis and that the fatigue had hampered his ability to work (his job required making deliveries for a shipping firm). Although the diagnosis had been a shock, he said he had left the hospital feeling “great, better than I’d felt in years.” For about a week after discharge, he described having enhanced energy and a sense of well-being, but he then began to feel anxious and restless. He slept poorly, unable to concentrate, and worried constantly about his health, finances, and family. He became less engaged with his family and stopped watching movies, normally his favorite pastime.

He denied having nightmares, flashbacks, avoidant behaviors, or racing thoughts. He also denied low mood, tearfulness, appetite changes, anhedonia, helplessness, hopelessness, or suicidality. He reported that he had started drinking daily 10 years earlier, stating that he enjoyed the taste of beer and liked socializing with friends after work. He developed tolerance to alcohol, needing to consume six to eight drinks per night to achieve the same effect. He described some withdrawal symptoms in the morning but did not drink during work hours; he underwent random testing due to his job as a truck driver. He did miss some family activities, preferring to drink, and this had been a source of marital conflict. He admitted feeling guilty about his alcohol use and its impact on him and his family. He denied using any alcohol since his hospitalization. He admitted to anger over having to undergo addiction counseling and had argued with the transplant team about this requirement. He denied having been an anxious person and considered himself able to handle most of life’s challenges without being overwhelmed. His family confirmed his description of himself and viewed his recent behavior as uncharacteristic.

On mental status examination, Mr. Jennings was a thin, jaundiced, tired-appearing man. His gait was normal, but he was fidgety while seated. He maintained eye contact and responded appropriately, although he repeatedly made comments like, “Something isn’t right” and “It’s not all in my head.” His affect was anxious and irritable, and his speech was terse. He appeared distracted but denied confusion and disorientation. He had no delusions or hallucinations. His thoughts were logical and coherent, without disorganization, and there was no latency to his responses. He scored 26 out of 30 on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment, missing points for recall and serial 7s. He scored in the normal range for Trail Making Test A and B but asked to have the instructions repeated for Trails B.
diagnosis:
1. Alcohol use disorder, moderate, in early remission
2. Medication-induced anxiety disorder (steroids)
